title: Reimaging Medieval Paris
description: In 1323, Jean de Jandun wrote that "Paris seems to have received from the Most-High the role of the earthly Paradise." Church, monarchy, merchants, and university created a unique urban environment that was nearly erased in the nineteenth century. This seminar reimagines Paris through its architectural survivors, including the Cathedral of Notre-Dame and the Sainte-Chapelle as well as descriptions by contemporary authors, and graphic documentation of key lost buildings, such as the Franciscan convent of Marie-Madeleine and the Collège de Cluny. Together, these sources recapture the medieval cityâs artistic energy and physical complexity, yet also reveal that institutional identity and social order were materialized by buildings and spaces. A major theme of this seminar centers on the evaluation of evidence in the study of historical monuments. Using SketchUp, an open-source design software, as a tool for reconstruction opens the way for an interactive engagement with techniques of Gothic design and construction. The process exposes the contradictions and limitations of written and visual records that demand strategies of informed speculation in pursuit of scholarship that is at once plausible and evocative.
instructordetail_html: Michael Davis
